title: The HOA really hates us, I think.
description: Just a quick note from the front-lines of our strange, ongoing battle with our Home Owner‚Äôs Association, who doesn‚Äôt think year-round 12-foot-skeletons are acceptable because skeletons are seasonal and Halloween is over. Bone Crawford remains standing. Happy early St. Patrick‚Äôs Day.
author: thebloggess
excerpt: Just a quick note from the front-lines of our strange, ongoing battle with our Home Owner‚Äôs Association, who doesn‚Äôt think year-round 12-foot-skeletons are acceptable because skeletons ‚Ä¶
text: Just a quick note from the front-lines of our strange, ongoing battle with our Home Owner‚Äôs Association, who doesn‚Äôt think year-round 12-foot-skeletons are acceptable because skeletons are seasonal and Halloween is over. Bone Crawford remains standing. Happy early St. Patrick‚Äôs Day. Post navigation 87 thoughts on ‚ÄúThe HOA really hates us, I think.‚Äù Read comments below or add one. This is the reason I will not ever live in a neighborhood with an HOA. THE HOA Board might hate you but I bet plenty of rank-and-file HOA members love you. Love it!!! But he needs a hat too‚Ä¶.. For one brief, delightful, moment I thought you‚Äôd used a shamrock in place of a fig leaf. üòÄ Hoping to see bunny ears for Easter. Same as those people who decorate the geese or flamingos in their yards. Perhaps your HOA would prefer a gaggle or flamboyance (Isn‚Äôt that the perfect term for ü¶©?) instead. üòà I like being in an HOA after a house by us became a dumping ground for bathtubs and refrigerators. It was in an expensive neighborhood and county. And then one we were considering buying elsewhere made the bathtubs and frig house look like a spa compared to the one next to the possible house. But I would want an exception in the bylaws that skeletons be allowed for all minor and major holidays. And other neat stuff. I LOVE that you have stood your ground on this for years now! 12 ft skeletons can definitely be a year-round feature to add Beauty and interest to the home and if somebody born on St Patrick‚Äôs Day who grew up in England and Chicago and New York you have made the first St Patrick‚Äôs Day decoration in my 62 years that I have liked I could have been way more into my birthday if they had just dressed up a 12-ft skeleton who knew!!? Bone Crawford remains standing, as he should. They are so wrong! 12-foot skeletons should be required. We love you Jenny!! Screw the HOA!! Some people down the street from us have one and they didn‚Äôt take theirs down until last month. I know they decorated it for Christmas because we walked by just before and I told my husband they should put a Santa hat on it and the next time we passed it was wearing one, which I thought was awesome. I wish they‚Äôd kept up the fight because I miss seeing the skelly. Thanks for spreading joy! I love Bone Crawford and think dressing them up for each holiday and season is awesome! I‚Äôd love to have someone creative and fun like your family in my community. HOAs are made up of people who want to live in similar look cookie cutter homes with no personality, and the HOA boards are made up of people who want to stamp out anything that doesn‚Äôt fit their idea of bland perfection. My HOA painted all our exterior doors white, when we live next to a city and a highway and near a highway-like state road, so all our doors look dirty all the time now from the pollution. There‚Äôs nothing I dislike more than having to wash my doors every week. They used to be painted medium grey, which looked much better and didn‚Äôt show dirt as much. Then they told us we couldn‚Äôt put up any exterior decor signs or garden statues or anything outside our units. Phooey on them! I hope you circulate a petition to all of the people in your complex to let Bone Crawford remain up year round as long as the outfit changes appropriately. A neighbor on on our cul de sac put out a USC flag, so my hubby put out a UCLA flag. Chaos! Then! I put out some lovely pink flamingos in the front yard. The flamingos were quite lovely and fit right in since we live in Palm Springs. No HOA, but people that still live here think I am a goofball. Did you know the company that made those flamingos for years went out of business? Sad but true. I just can‚Äôt help myself sometimes‚Ä¶..ü¶© You‚Äôve inspired me. I wonder what kind of large creature I could get that would annoy our HOA? It would be fun to dress it up for holidays. I think you should nominate Dorothy Barker to serve on the HOA board. there is a house on my way to work in Scarborough, ME that has a year round skeleton like yours they dress up for every season or holiday. it is THE BEST. i often wonder if they are custom-making the outfits due to size. üôÇ your HOA needs to to understand that you are not alone. this is a national thing. Love the outfit. Do your HOA CCRs actually specify that ‚Äúholiday‚Äù decorations can‚Äôt be up year round? Ours used to fine people, but then we looked at the Association documents and it did not say anything about ‚Äúholiday‚Äù decorations, so the complainers had no leg to stand on. Now, we have folks that have holiday light strings that change colors for the various seasons ‚Äî I‚Äôll take those any day over the front yards covered in cement that look like used car lots. You were very restrained with where the shamrocks are coming from. We put ours up to keep it from damage. I love it too much. I also have the 9 foot dragon. There seems to be some kind of special day every month, so I think they‚Äôre safe! It‚Äôs good to see an HOA get boned! SKELETONS ARE NOT SEASONAL!!! Each and every one of us is a walking skeleton with skin. I don‚Äôt consider myself seasonal. ü§£ We have one in our front yard (no HOA). We‚Äôre using it as a trellis for honeysuckle üôÇ Why in the name of sanity do you live in an HOA???? You need to track down every obscure holiday to justify Bone Crawford‚Äôs existence just to piss them off. Bone Crawford Forever! Well, our country is led by Nazis, so people like this don‚Äôt surprise me. They‚Äôre the kind of people who voted for the orange dictator. Bone Crawford should be able to stay year-round!!! HOAs are horrible, IMHO!! I‚Äôm too much of a rebel to live in an HOA neighborhood‚Ä¶.though the pics of your house are beautiful. That‚Äôs a ‚Äúhill I would die on‚Äù. A house I pass on my way home has a ‚Äúlife-size‚Äù Sasquatch cut out that they seasonally decorate. It makes my day when I drive by and he‚Äôs wearing or holding something new. Fight the power, Jenny!!! More outfits for Bone Crawford! Your 12 foot tall skeleton is part of biology education. Scientific communication to the public is very important and its abdrigment is a violation of the first amendment. You can tell the HOA that a random internet scientist thinks your skeleton is important and awesome and in no way halloween decor. I‚Äôm right there with you! One commenter said a few words about people dressing up their yard ornaments. My one flamingo (not only, but the only one in the front yard) next to the steps into the house gets a witch hat and broom at Halloween, Santa hat and neck scarf for Christmas, and whenever a family member has a birthday, a party hat! Take that, HOA! I have it on good authority that a 5 xl t-shirt fits these guys, in case you ever wanted to make a custom shirt for him via cafepress or what have you‚Ä¶ Stay strong, Bone Crawford!! The folks who try to direct other peoples lives or expect your home to not stand out are frustrated little generals. Sorry you are in that situation. Been that, stuck there, evryone in family told us to move but we wouldnt, I will suggest you think seriously about it to save yourself s much stress. Alternatively how about weird lights inside your windows all night. As it should be! St. Patty will back you ‚Äì HOA is toast. Bone Crawford is awesome! I wish I had his brother here. I wonder what my neighbors would think. üòÇ Skeletons are definitely seasonal and are only appropriate for four seasons out of the year. If it isn‚Äôt Winter, Spring, Summer, or Fall, you should bring the skeleton inside. I suggest joining or creating a death cult so that your friend Bone is an expression of your religion, kind of like how some of us have a mezzuzah on our doors. I think you could do something creative with transgender mice. Mouse in drag Awesome! Love those skellies. Sorry you live in an HOA. I could never live in one. My yard is more for nature than perfect looks. It‚Äôs great having trees all around giving you privacy. Stand firm! I love your individuality! üòç It‚Äôs scary how much power the law gives HOAs in Texas, so just make sure technically in the right; and put aside some money for a lawyer. Oh Goddess HOA? I‚Äôd have to kill myself and add to the skeleton family haha I tried to emulate you and leave my multi-color, programmable string lights up and change them for every holiday, but I received a letter that we can‚Äôt have ANY decorations up except from October 1-January 1. I‚Äôm so happy to be leaving this HOA!! I concur with the bunny ears suggestion. Also a giant basket fill with eggs and if you can find/make them ..skeletal Peeps! Or regular giant sized Peeps. One of the many reasons why I‚Äôm glad I live in an old-fashioned neighborhood (single-family dwellings built in 1947 for returning WWII vets). No Home Owner‚Äôs Association. Best way to make sure the HOA isn‚Äôt run by a bunch of spoil sports is to get on the HOA board yourself. Then you could make a rule that every house is required to have a holiday decoration or 12 foot skeleton . A neighborhood we used to live in had an HOA that met once/year in the spring for a cookout, did the business part in 10 minutes, then started grilling and drinking. And that community had a roving band of 25 or 30 pink flamingos that would move (be moved?) to different yards. In all seriousness, check the covenants, conditions and restrictions and other HOA documents and see what they really have the power to really require or prohibit. Can‚Äôt wait to see the bunny ears and fluffy tail. I love him! And HOAs are dumb! HOAs are petty domestic fascists. Hang in there! But what would HOA even do, if you werent living there? You make work for lonly people! Be proud üòÄ Bone Crawford remains standing! Wait a second. Did I miss Bone being dressed for Mardi Gras? I think Bone looks extra happy in shamrocks. Fuck ‚Äòem if they can‚Äôt take a joke. And good for you for not caving! Love you, Jenny. The only thing she needs is a green hat! What is an HOA and why can they tell you what to do with your own yard? I‚Äôm not from the USA so I don‚Äôt understand (unless you are renting?)? But if you own the house and the grounds why are they allowed to tell you what to do with it? (Some neighborhoods have Home Owner‚Äôs Associations that enforce rules of the nieghborhood. Ours is a bit stricter than a typical one, but they can be helpful if you have a neighbor who is not keeping up a place or causing a danger. A house behind me was unoccupied for about 8 years and they made the owners keep the yard from getting too overgrown, which was nice bc it‚Äôs a good way to get mice. In my neighborhood you sign up for the HOA when you move in and pay for it each year. ~ Jenny) Can a skeleton say ‚ÄòVive la R√©sistance!‚Äô? It‚Äôs not easy being green The house near mine which has the 12-foot skeleton and the 10-foot werewolf added a bigger (13-foot?) tree skeleton thing (groot style head skeleton body all looking like tree bark) it‚Äôs fun to see if they find something every October to add to the year-round yard display. Last month one of my neighbors had a skeleton in his tree with a heart on its pelvis (we don‚Äôt live in an HOA). ‚ÄúIt was a skeleton with a heart on.‚Äù Now say that out loud and wonder with me if they did it on purpose. Yes, I‚Äôm a 10-year-old boy. Long live Bone Crawford! üíÄ üçÄ I can understand where they are coming from and your point of view, but face it, you signed the contract when you bought or rented into the place. it‚Äôs on you to do your research. and obey their rules. I grew up in a voluntary HOA community and they are not anything like the HOAs of today. it‚Äôs mostly yard of the month, community garage sales, neighborhood watches, and parties. which is why I refuse to consider buying or renting a house with one. the only way to change this ruling is to get elected to the board. you might not like their stance, but have you asked your neighbors what THEY think of your skeleton? they‚Äôre the ones who have to look at it every day. perhaps they think the joke is wearing thin. (That‚Äôs true, but I‚Äôve never had a complaint from a neighbor, only compliments. üôÇ ~ Jenny) Well done! (I never want to ever have to deal with an HOA!) Keep the faith and keep fighting. I‚Äôm curious ‚Äì is the HOA threatening legal action?? If they just hate you, who cares? I love that you are making Bone Crawford a member of your family. They seem like a guardian at your front door. No HOA for me but I used a 4 foot hairy spider as the center of a fence display; spider in a web, as Santa, giving roses to the pink flamingo, spring motif with flamingo, baby flamingo joins the family and then, no joke, the wind somehow carried the spider across the street and I found him in the woods and so ended the fence fun. It started because I wanted to stretch my creativity and not spend any money. In the end I took the ‚Äúweb‚Äù of fake flowers and turned them into a peace sign. My neighbours told me they liked it and apparently small children had to be consoled when the spider disappeared. Flying the freak flag (or the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm other‚Äù) is so important right now; making it with a sense of love and joy brings that energy into a world and our that can feel dark and dismal. I have fought a TX HOA and won. My HOA president at the time is the rat bastard who got the laws changed to allow HOAs and MUDs to sue you and collect damages and their legal fees. Check your deed, there is always an escape hatch. Ours was to get over 50% of the property owners to sign a petition, with notarized signatures, and filed with the county clerk, to change said restriction. All this then became part of every property owners deeds!! The HOA/MUD had sued us for small garden shed that matched the house and couldn‚Äôt be seen from the street. They were not happy when their attorney had to tell them at the public meeting they had to drop the suit and why. I was right there in the front row smiling as their cocky grins faded from their faces. 20 years later I still despise the nazi bastards, but then I remember how I made them cry uncle in public and continued to hold their feet to the fire the rest of the time we lived there. I will NEVER live in an HOA or MUD again. We‚Äôre in a downtown Austin neighborhood with the coolest house and artwork, etc. Read the Deed and fight! And Bone Crawford is awesome. When you found the life size T. rex I told my kids I was going to remove the dying tree from our front yard and replace it with a life size T rex! I told them wo could decorate it for every season! A giant Easter bonnet and a basket to hang on his tiny arm! An Uncle Sam outfit ! Christmas lights! I think a year round 12 skeleton is perfectly acceptable, and so does my neighbor. Theirs is at Patrick‚Äôs decorated as well I am scared to leave this reply, because I see a crowd of people all cheering you on, and I don‚Äôt want to be bullied, but I don‚Äôt think agree with leaving this up year-round, especially with an HOA. I love your writing, and your stories, but HOAs aren‚Äôt the evil things people here are saying they are. Some of us really do like having lawns clipped to the same height at the same time, and a similar look and feel to the neighborhood. I live where we have an HOA, and am known as ‚Äúthe Halloween guy‚Äù because of how much we decorate. But my decorations are down on Nov 1. And I would feel upset and kind of like you were challenging me to a conflict by leaving it up year round. I‚Äôm sorry, but it would make me constantly anxious that I liked you as a neighbor but disliked what you were doing üôÅ (This is a totally fair opinion, friend. I will say though that I‚Äôve never had a complaint from a neighbor -and in fact get compliments from them all the time ‚Äì and you can‚Äôt actually see Bone Crawford unless you‚Äôre standing directly in front of my house because she‚Äôs tucked in the back of my porch. üôÇ ~ Jenny) Long may Bone Crawford stand! Vive le squelette (long live the skeleton) Jenny, I think he needs to be a permanent fixture, dressed for the season. I want to help clothe him appropriately. Right now a green bowler would be fitting. And until the end of May? June? Just add flowers and make him a gardener. Dollar Tree bucket & tools, some fake flowers growing from his ribs? Perfect for the entire growing season! I‚Äôd love to know who in the HOA is only using their skeleton seasonally? Because, personally, I‚Äôm anatomically dependent on my daily, and certainly wouldn‚Äôt consider it merely decorative. Their argument may be logically flawed. Long live (die? Stand? Reign?) Bone Crawford! A friend had a similar battle over a really classy 7ft Bigfoot statue. HOA‚Äôs have no taste. When I worked as a Nurse-Educator there was a life-size skeleton in my office, left from a previous occupant. The first day of every month I decorated him/her(?) to reflect the holidays. Stocking cap & scarf in January, a heart where a heart would belong for February, etc. The dollar store was my friend. The skeleton faced the doorway. It was the first thing you saw when my office door was open. More people than usual used that hallway the first few days of the month No one ever said anything. Ever. I am such a dork. (did I mention I taught Operating Room nursing)? There‚Äôs a house near me that has an entire skeleton family that stays out year-round, and they decorate them for every holiday and season. It‚Äôs 100% delightful. One of my favorites was last summer when they had them wearing goggles and carrying pool noodles and floaties. They‚Äôre currently decked out as leprechauns. I didn‚Äôt realize skeletons were seasonal. Leave a Reply ALL THE COOL KIDS ADVERTISE HERE: I fucking love these people & not just because they support my wine-slushee habit: Flourish in Progress: (T)hug Life: Part hood. Part good. Pregnancy Calendar at Alpha Mom: Amalah‚Äôs week-by-week guide to the miracle of pregnancy and all the various indignities that come with it. The Mack Files: Digesting life in bite-sized pieces through the lens of clich√©s, quotes & ‚Äútruisms‚Äù. ¬†Often irreverent, always honest. Barking at the Moon: If your dog is your furry child, you will laugh out loud at Tracy Beckerman‚Äôs book about her family & a one-dog wrecking ball named Riley. Welcome to xanaru: A mostly funny blog about my quest for happiness through stories, friendship, Great Danes and¬†indiscriminate swearing. How the Hell Did I Not Know That?: Humorist Lucie Frost shares daily Instagram reels with learnings of the day‚Äîwords, music, whatever‚Äìwith plenty of laughs and all the curse words. Beautiful Writers book: Writers! This coming-of-career memoir (w/ the BEST advice from celeb authors, real shit you haven‚Äôt heard) is life. A page-turning beach read doubling as how-to. #Magic His Lies Did Not Erase Me: Plagued by nightmares, Stacie Ann Leininger turned to writing to help her cope with the horrors of being forced into silence for several decades after the death and cover-up of her boyfriend when they were just 15. This important collection of poetry is the result. No Pithy Phrase: Between cancer, creatures, and the horde, there‚Äôs always something weird going on over here. The witchy writing freak flags are flying. Sarah Ramsey, Public Relations: Want more media coverage for your work? Most reporters get at least 50 pitches in their inbox each week, but are able to use fewer than 25% of those. Rise to the top of a reporter‚Äôs list by hiring a pro (me!) to write your press release. Butterfly Goo: The Down and Dirty Truth of Transformation¬†Transformation isn‚Äôt pretty, but this hilarious memoir is filled with the mishaps, mistakes, misadventures, and mess of one heroine‚Äôs journey. Includes playground areas if¬†you want to make changes in your own life. Hyperbole and a Half by Allie Brosh: SO GOOD.
html:
Just a quick note from the front-lines of our strange, ongoing battle with our Home Owner‚Äôs Association, who doesn‚Äôt think year-round 12-foot-skeletons are acceptable because skeletons are seasonal and Halloween is over.

Bone Crawford remains standing.

Happy early St. Patrick‚Äôs Day.

Post navigation

87 thoughts on ‚ÄúThe HOA really hates us, I think.‚Äù

Read comments below or add one.

  1. This is the reason I will not ever live in a neighborhood with an HOA.

  2. THE HOA Board might hate you but I bet plenty of rank-and-file HOA members love you.

  3. Love it!!! But he needs a hat too‚Ä¶..

  4. For one brief, delightful, moment I thought you‚Äôd used a shamrock in place of a fig leaf. üòÄ

  5. Hoping to see bunny ears for Easter.

  6. Same as those people who decorate the geese or flamingos in their yards. Perhaps your HOA would prefer a gaggle or flamboyance (Isn‚Äôt that the perfect term for ü¶©?) instead. üòà

  7. I like being in an HOA after a house by us became a dumping ground for bathtubs and refrigerators. It was in an expensive neighborhood and county. And then one we were considering buying elsewhere made the bathtubs and frig house look like a spa compared to the one next to the possible house.

    But I would want an exception in the bylaws that skeletons be allowed for all minor and major holidays. And other neat stuff.

  8. I LOVE that you have stood your ground on this for years now!

  10. 12 ft skeletons can definitely be a year-round feature to add Beauty and interest to the home and if somebody born on St Patrick‚Äôs Day who grew up in England and Chicago and New York you have made the first St Patrick‚Äôs Day decoration in my 62 years that I have liked
    I could have been way more into my birthday if they had just dressed up a 12-ft skeleton who knew!!?

  11. Bone Crawford remains standing, as he should.

  12. They are so wrong! 12-foot skeletons should be required.

  13. We love you Jenny!! Screw the HOA!!

  14. Some people down the street from us have one and they didn‚Äôt take theirs down until last month. I know they decorated it for Christmas because we walked by just before and I told my husband they should put a Santa hat on it and the next time we passed it was wearing one, which I thought was awesome. I wish they‚Äôd kept up the fight because I miss seeing the skelly. Thanks for spreading joy!

  15. I love Bone Crawford and think dressing them up for each holiday and season is awesome! I‚Äôd love to have someone creative and fun like your family in my community.
    HOAs are made up of people who want to live in similar look cookie cutter homes with no personality, and the HOA boards are made up of people who want to stamp out anything that doesn‚Äôt fit their idea of bland perfection.
    My HOA painted all our exterior doors white, when we live next to a city and a highway and near a highway-like state road, so all our doors look dirty all the time now from the pollution. There‚Äôs nothing I dislike more than having to wash my doors every week. They used to be painted medium grey, which looked much better and didn‚Äôt show dirt as much. Then they told us we couldn‚Äôt put up any exterior decor signs or garden statues or anything outside our units. Phooey on them!
    I hope you circulate a petition to all of the people in your complex to let Bone Crawford remain up year round as long as the outfit changes appropriately.

  16. A neighbor on on our cul de sac put out a USC flag, so my hubby put out a UCLA flag. Chaos! Then! I put out some lovely pink flamingos in the front yard. The flamingos were quite lovely and fit right in since we live in Palm Springs. No HOA, but people that still live here think I am a goofball. Did you know the company that made those flamingos for years went out of business? Sad but true. I just can‚Äôt help myself sometimes‚Ä¶..ü¶©

  19. You‚Äôve inspired me. I wonder what kind of large creature I could get that would annoy our HOA? It would be fun to dress it up for holidays.

  20. I think you should nominate Dorothy Barker to serve on the HOA board.

  21. there is a house on my way to work in Scarborough, ME that has a year round skeleton like yours they dress up for every season or holiday. it is THE BEST. i often wonder if they are custom-making the outfits due to size. üôÇ your HOA needs to to understand that you are not alone. this is a national thing.

  22. Love the outfit.

    Do your HOA CCRs actually specify that ‚Äúholiday‚Äù decorations can‚Äôt be up year round? Ours used to fine people, but then we looked at the Association documents and it did not say anything about ‚Äúholiday‚Äù decorations, so the complainers had no leg to stand on. Now, we have folks that have holiday light strings that change colors for the various seasons ‚Äî I‚Äôll take those any day over the front yards covered in cement that look like used car lots.

  23. You were very restrained with where the shamrocks are coming from.

  24. We put ours up to keep it from damage. I love it too much. I also have the 9 foot dragon.

  26. There seems to be some kind of special day every month, so I think they‚Äôre safe! It‚Äôs good to see an HOA get boned!

  27. SKELETONS ARE NOT SEASONAL!!! Each and every one of us is a walking skeleton with skin. I don‚Äôt consider myself seasonal. ü§£

  29. We have one in our front yard (no HOA). We‚Äôre using it as a trellis for honeysuckle üôÇ

  30. Why in the name of sanity do you live in an HOA????

  32. You need to track down every obscure holiday to justify Bone Crawford‚Äôs existence just to piss them off. Bone Crawford Forever!

  33. Well, our country is led by Nazis, so people like this don‚Äôt surprise me. They‚Äôre the kind of people who voted for the orange dictator.

  34. Bone Crawford should be able to stay year-round!!! HOAs are horrible, IMHO!! I‚Äôm too much of a rebel to live in an HOA neighborhood‚Ä¶.though the pics of your house are beautiful. That‚Äôs a ‚Äúhill I would die on‚Äù.

  35. A house I pass on my way home has a ‚Äúlife-size‚Äù Sasquatch cut out that they seasonally decorate. It makes my day when I drive by and he‚Äôs wearing or holding something new.

  37. Fight the power, Jenny!!! More outfits for Bone Crawford!

  38. Your 12 foot tall skeleton is part of biology education. Scientific communication to the public is very important and its abdrigment is a violation of the first amendment. You can tell the HOA that a random internet scientist thinks your skeleton is important and awesome and in no way halloween decor.

  39. I‚Äôm right there with you! One commenter said a few words about people dressing up their yard ornaments. My one flamingo (not only, but the only one in the front yard) next to the steps into the house gets a witch hat and broom at Halloween, Santa hat and neck scarf for Christmas, and whenever a family member has a birthday, a party hat! Take that, HOA!

  40. I have it on good authority that a 5 xl t-shirt fits these guys, in case you ever wanted to make a custom shirt for him via cafepress or what have you‚Ä¶

  41. Stay strong, Bone Crawford!!

  42. The folks who try to direct other peoples lives or expect your home to not stand out are frustrated little generals. Sorry you are in that situation. Been that, stuck there, evryone in family told us to move but we wouldnt, I will suggest you think seriously about it to save yourself s much stress. Alternatively how about weird lights inside your windows all night.

  43. As it should be! St. Patty will back you ‚Äì HOA is toast.

  44. Bone Crawford is awesome! I wish I had his brother here. I wonder what my neighbors would think. üòÇ

  45. Skeletons are definitely seasonal and are only appropriate for four seasons out of the year. If it isn‚Äôt Winter, Spring, Summer, or Fall, you should bring the skeleton inside.

    I suggest joining or creating a death cult so that your friend Bone is an expression of your religion, kind of like how some of us have a mezzuzah on our doors.

  46. I think you could do something creative with transgender mice. Mouse in drag

  47. Awesome! Love those skellies. Sorry you live in an HOA. I could never live in one. My yard is more for nature than perfect looks. It‚Äôs great having trees all around giving you privacy.

  48. Stand firm! I love your individuality! üòç

  49. It‚Äôs scary how much power the law gives HOAs in Texas, so just make sure technically in the right; and put aside some money for a lawyer.

  50. Oh Goddess HOA? I‚Äôd have to kill myself and add to the skeleton family haha

  51. I tried to emulate you and leave my multi-color, programmable string lights up and change them for every holiday, but I received a letter that we can‚Äôt have ANY decorations up except from October 1-January 1. I‚Äôm so happy to be leaving this HOA!!

  52. I concur with the bunny ears suggestion. Also a giant basket fill with eggs and if you can find/make them ..skeletal Peeps! Or regular giant sized Peeps.

  53. One of the many reasons why I‚Äôm glad I live in an old-fashioned neighborhood (single-family dwellings built in 1947 for returning WWII vets). No Home Owner‚Äôs Association.

  54. Best way to make sure the HOA isn‚Äôt run by a bunch of spoil sports is to get on the HOA board yourself. Then you could make a rule that every house is required to have a holiday decoration or 12 foot skeleton . A neighborhood we used to live in had an HOA that met once/year in the spring for a cookout, did the business part in 10 minutes, then started grilling and drinking. And that community had a roving band of 25 or 30 pink flamingos that would move (be moved?) to different yards.
